title: Referring to tool lints with paths that have redundant segments in the middle works

labels.name: A-lint
labels.description: Area: Lints (warnings about flaws in source code) such as unused_mut.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
I tried these code:

```rust
#[forbid(clippy::no::matter::how::many::useless::segments::here::it::always::works::empty_loop)]
fn _foo() -> ! {
    loop {}
}
```

```rust
#![forbid(rustdoc::no::matter::how::many::useless::segments::here::it::always::works::all)] // at least in crate root
```

I expected to see this happen: `clippy` or `rustdoc` reported them as unknown lints.

Instead, this happened: both [`clippy`](https://play.rust-lang.org/?edition=2018&code=%23%5Bforbid(clippy%3A%3Afoo%3A%3Aempty_loop)%5D%0Afn%20_foo()%20-%3E%20!%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20loop%20%7B%7D%0A%7D%0A%0A%23%5Bforbid(clippy%3A%3Afoo%3A%3Abar%3A%3Aempty_loop)%5D%0Afn%20_foo_bar()%20-%3E%20!%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20loop%20%7B%7D%0A%7D%0A%0A%23%5Bforbid(clippy%3A%3Afoo%3A%3Abar%3A%3Abaz%3A%3Aempty_loop)%5D%0Afn%20_foo_bar_baz()%20-%3E%20!%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20loop%20%7B%7D%0A%7D%0A%0A%23%5Bforbid(clippy%3A%3Ano%3A%3Amatter%3A%3Ahow%3A%3Amany%3A%3Auseless%3A%3Asegments%3A%3Ahere%3A%3Ait%3A%3Aalways%3A%3Aworks%3A%3Aempty_loop)%5D%0Afn%20_sigh()%20-%3E%20!%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20loop%20%7B%7D%0A%7D%0A) and `rustdoc` worked as if I specified `clippy::empty_loop` or `rustdoc::all`, without `no::matter::how::many::useless::segments::here::it::always::works`.

#### Meta
`rustc` version: 1.53.0-nightly (07e0e2ec268c140e607e1ac7f49f145612d0f597 2021-03-24)

#### Background
I discovered this through  rust-analyzer, which tried to auto-complete something like `#[allow(clippy::empty_loo` with `#[allow(clippy::clippy::empty_loop)]`, and then I found that syntax actually works.
